column1: Gliomas are tumors that grow in various parts of the brain.

Optic gliomas can affect: - One or both of the optic nerves that carry visual information to the brain from each eye - The optic chiasm, the area where the optic nerves cross each other in front of the hypothalamus of the brain An optic glioma may also grow along with a hypothalamic glioma.
Most optic gliomas are slow-growing and noncancerous (benign) and occur in children, almost always before age 20.
